reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

description.narrative: The project contributes to the development problem of youth unemployment and inactive citizenship causing hopelessness and social evils such as crime violence poverty alcoholism prostitution and abuse. Namibian economy is not generating enough job opportun ities despite the positive economic growth. Thus there is an urgent need to build in a mechanism for targeted youth support.The projects principal outcomes are: 1) the capacities of youth have been strengthened on human rights roles and responsibilities; 2 ) the provision of targeted support for the most marginalized youth; 3) the increased civic engagement advocacy and dialogue between youth community agencies and service providers. The central activities are: the development of a curriculum on rights educa tion; the formation of youth clubs; training of pastors and community campaigns for the re-integration of young ex-offenders; training of mentors to support teen mothers; training of teen mothers on life skills and parenting; fostering the marginalized you th employability in cooperation with companies; training of civil servants on participatory youth work; strengthening the equal access of youth to digital world. The project aims at the increased engagement of civil society with the most marginalized youth . As such Societies have become more democratic and better-functioning is the priority area of Finland's development policy to which the project contributes.Human rights and gender equality are strongly emphasized as an alarming share of youth notably girl s has been left out from education and employment. The project respects and addresses their human rights and well-being by empowering them to become subjects of their own development and the society as a whole. The project respects climate sustainability. The project will be carried out by the Helsinki Deaconess Institute the provider of the nationally recognised and benchmarked VAMOS Youth services and the Department of Diakonia and Social Services of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Namibia. The direct beneficiaries are the marginalized youth ages 15 to 35 with special reference to ex-offenders and teen mothers.
